results.title: Biden Sticks to Afghan Deadline, Resisting Pleas to Extend Evacuation
results.abstract: The American withdrawal coincided with a threat by the Taliban to stop Afghans from traveling to the airport, an ominous sign that the window may be slamming shut for thousands of people desperate to leave.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Imprisoned Chinese Citizen Journalist Is Severely Ill From a Hunger Strike
results.abstract: Zhang Zhan was sentenced to four years in prison for documenting the Covid-19 outbreak in Wuhan. She now weighs less than 90 pounds, her former lawyer says.
results.byline: By Amy Chang Chien and Austin Ramzy
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Zhang Zhan in Wuhan, China, last year. She declined to appeal her conviction, telling her lawyers that she refused to acknowledge the validity of the legal process used to imprison her.

des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Najibullah, his wife Zeineb, and their twins at a bus station in Van, Turkey, after crossing illegally from Iran. They were detained in a migrant facility and sent back to Iran within days.

results.title: F.D.A. Fully Approves Pfizer-BioNTech’s Vaccine, a First for a Covid-19 Shot
results.abstract: The move was expected to kick off a round of new vaccination mandates from hospitals, schools and private companies.
results.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

multimedia.caption: An inoculation site in the Bronx offering the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine last week. More than 92 million Americans have been fully vaccinated with Pfizer doses.

results.title: Taliban Reject Extended Deadline as U.S. Races to Finish Evacuation
results.abstract: Tens of thousands are still hoping for rescue, with priority recently being given to Americans over Afghan allies, according to a U.S. official and those involved in the effort.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Megan K. Stack
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Afghans desperate to flee the country wait in a field outside Kabul’s airport on Monday.

results.title: Hawaii’s governor discourages travelers from visiting as virus rates surge in the state.
results.abstract: With hospitals filling up and large gatherings banned on Oahu for the next four weeks, “it’s not a good time to travel to the islands,” Gov. David Ige said.
results.byline: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Kaly Soto

multimedia.caption: Hikers at a waterfall on the Maunawili trail in Honolulu in April. The popular hike is often crowded with visitors.

results.title: The top U.S. officer in Afghanistan talks with the Taliban almost every day.
results.abstract: Other officers have also engaged with Taliban commanders on specific security and threat reduction issues, a partnership of necessity after 20 years of war.
results.byline: By Eric Schmitt

results.title: The Taliban holds first meeting of religious leaders since taking Kabul.
results.abstract: Hundreds of imams and leaders of religious schools met as the Taliban outlined its vision for education and its new government.
results.byline: By Matthieu Aikins

multimedia.caption: Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban’s chief spokesman, spoke at the Loya Jirga Hall on Monday before hundreds of religious leaders.
multimedia.copyright: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

results.title: Afghan Fiasco Raises Hard Questions for Europe
results.abstract: Once again, the United States has dragged its NATO allies into an embarrassing mess they had warned against, bringing calls for more autonomy. But the price of independence is steep.
results.byline: By Steven Erlanger
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: American Vet Returns to Italy to Greet ‘Bambini’ He Last Saw in 1944
results.abstract: The daughter of a World War II veteran used the internet to track down three children he was photographed with 77 years ago — after almost firing on them. On Monday, they finally met face to face.
results.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Martin Adler, a 97-year-old former American soldier, with the Naldi siblings in Bologna, Italy, on Monday.
multimedia.copyright: Elisabetta Baracchi/EPA, via Shutterstock
